A Californian's Tour of Russia
Californian visits Russia in the winter

A Californian’s Tour of Russia is now a book! →

Ole!

Posted on January 8, 2010 by candi

Chad wanted to make Sasha and Zhenia fajitas tonight, but it was difficult finding the right ingredients. No refried beans, so Chad used a can of beans he found, not sure what kind, no limes (hmmm), couldn’t find cilantro (his herb garden is still only sprouts), BUT we have the cuantro, lemons and tequila, so, we’ll be just fine.

He’s making his own flour tortillas and chips, guacamole (we found avocados) and salsa (fresh tomatoes). He makes the best fajitas, I’m looking forward to it. AND he kicked me out of the kitchen! It’s so nice to have a son who loves to cook.

The next day:It was fantastic, Sasha and Zhenia loved the spices AND the margaritas! They left very happy and with a tub of salsa. Zhenia and Chad both speak Russian and English, Sasha understands and reads English and I have no knowledge of Russian, but we all had a great time, laughing, telling stories and making toasts to friendship.

Oh, btw…it’s -33C. outside. That’s -27.4Fahrenheit!!!! MINUS! Even the locals are calling that cold. As much as I’d love to go out and shop, see the sights….I think maybe not. I found the following:
In calm conditions at -29°C a well clothed person is in little danger, a light wind of 10mph gives the same effect as a temperature of -44°C when exposed flesh can freeze in a minute or so. A breeze of 25mph gives an equivalent of -66°C with severe danger to exposed flesh within seconds rather than minutes. *Yikes! No wonder I was getting ice cream headaches..lolwww.coolantarctica.com/Antarctica%20fact%20file/science/cold_humans.htm href=”http://2scottmontgomery.blogspot.com.

But, I’m leaving tomorrow morning for home, where it’s a roasting 70 F. Only a difference of 97.4 degrees. Eek.
It’s Friday night, and instead of their usual Friday night shrimp boil, the group (Sasha, Zhenia, Ana, Julia and Chad) are taking me to a Russian restaurant for dinner for my last night. I’m flattered.
As it turned out, we didn’t go to a Russian restaurant, but a Japanese one (sushi is very popular over there). It was really great food and a fun atmosphere.

The ever-present disco ball added a sense of celebration to the room. In fact, they were celebrating. This day started a week-long festival of the end of winter. They celebrate with eating blinis of all kinds. These are with berries.


Blinis are crepe-like pancakes filled with cheese and topped with berries. Of course, the different kinds of blinis are endless.

Chad, Sasha, Julia, Ana and Zhenia.
When we finished, I wanted to get photos of their great furs. OMG, such quality and style.


Beautiful. Chad’s wool coat is almost warm enough for him, but he’ll get a fur one soon; we were in “vacation for Mom” mode when this shot was taken.


I already miss not only Chad (of course), but this tight group of friends he has. What wonderful people they all are. As we were leaving Zhenia gave me a cute little charm with amber and a fantastic bottle of brandy with a vanilla taste to it. It’s delicious. I feel much better knowing that Chad has such great friends to help him in his life in Russia, teaching each other their respective languages, cooking and introducing new foods to each other, and most importantly, laughing and enjoying their times together. I hope they come to California soon (I think it’ll really happen!) so I can introduce 80 degree weather to them. lol. (Joking…they have air conditioners everywhere, remember?) Hope to see you soon!
